unnormalised: Okay, so you're asking about the future of online learning in India, right? Well, it's HUGE, bhai! EdTech is seriously booming. My younger brother, Rohan, is totally hooked on these online classes. He gets tutored from 8 PM to 10 PM almost every night.
normalised: Okay, so you're asking about the future of online learning in India, right? Well, it's huge, brother! EdTech is seriously booming. My younger brother, Rohan, is totally hooked on these online classes. He gets tutored from eight P-M to ten P-M almost every night.

unnormalised: Remember those boring textbooks? Gone! Now it's all about interactive video lessons, quizzes, and even virtual reality stuff. Companies like Byju's and Vedantu are making learning way more engaging. They're spending crores on marketing, too - you see their ads everywhere. He says he finds Physics and Maths much easier to understand now - he’s scoring 85% + on all his tests.

He says he finds Physics and Maths much easier to understand now - he’s scoring eighty five percent plus on all his tests.

unnormalised: And it's not just for kids. My aunt, she's learning coding on Udemy at age 45! She wants to "upskill" and get a better job. She finishes work, has her dinner, and then attends her online class at 9:30 PM. Online learning has opened up opportunities for so many ppl who couldn't access traditional education. Even remote villages are getting connected thanks to cheap internet and smartphones.

unnormalised: The thing is, online learning isn't perfect. There are connectivity issues in many parts of India. Not everyone can afford a decent laptop or a stable internet connection. The digital divide is real. Then there's the screen time problem – too much staring at devices. Rohan’s eye doctor said he needs to take a break every 20 minutes.

The digital divide is real. Then there's the screen time problem – too much staring at devices. Rohan’s eye doctor said he needs to take a break every twenty minutes.

unnormalised: Also, motivation can be a challenge. It's easy to get distracted when you're learning at home. No one is physically watching you. The teacher is not right there, breathing down your neck! You have to be disciplined. Some of Rohan's friends have told him that they often get distracted and start watching reels instead of attending the lecture.

unnormalised: But overall, I think online learning and EdTech are here to stay. It's flexible, affordable, and can reach anyone, anywhere. It's changing the way we learn and how we think about education. As the internet gets faster and cheaper, and as more people get access to technology, online learning will only get bigger. My prediction? By 2025, over 50% of Indian students will be using some form of online learning, from primary school all the way up to post-grad.
